I was looking for something reasonable in price and decent enough to sleep in - I got a lot more, considering some of the places I've stayed at that price. It is very, very nice.

Reviews.Title: “I'd stay there again.”
Reviews.Author: uglyagnes
Reviews.Content: I called the hotel and got a rate of $119 (Plus $30 a night parking fee) for that price I would say the hotel was above average. I didn't have any problems checking in. The valet serviece was a little slow for the price, but its a busy street so you can't expect too much. The French Quarter is just a 10 minute walk and the Hotel is a safe and quieter neighborhood. The Queen Deluxe room was clean and modern, maybe a little small but ok for two people. The bathroom and shower and were nice, and we were restocked with aveda products everyday. The halls were very dark, and the room was somewhat dark too. The bathroom has a dimmer switch which we didn't find until the 2nd day, as the bathroom was getting darker and darker and darker...

Reviews.Title: “Very satisfied”
Reviews.Author: Reviewer71
Reviews.Content: I had to stay in New Orleans for 3 nights during a conference, held at the Sheraton, which is just 50 yards away on Canal St. The Sheraton was almost twice as expensive, so I decided for the this one, and I am happy with my choice. The room was clean and perfectly adequate. I asked for a quiet room and I got it. The lobby is very nice and it has a small but very lively and trendy bar which I never went to, but was clearly popular among a nice crowd every night. The hotel is 5-10 minutes away from the French Quarter and the service was friendly and cooperative. My room was not cleaned the last night I stayed but I didn't care that much. Overall a very good choice. The only problem is that Canal street has very poor dining options but, again, the French Quarter is very nearby.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect location, perfect staff”
Reviews.Author: calendar1
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just took our first trip to New Orleans. Having read many of the reviews on this site, I decided to book the International House. It was the best decision I could have made. The hotel is located across the street from the French Quarter, and a short block to the St. Charles trolley. The hotel is very quiet, clean, and the staff was very knowledgeable. We berated the front desk with questions about restaurants, tours, and live music venues- they were spot on about everything. The only downside is that their breakfast consists of granola bars and cold coffee. I would stay there again on my next trip.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, but over-rated”
Reviews.Author: butterfern
Reviews.Content: The good: Location was great. Room was spacious and nicely decorated. Bathroom was lovely - and huge. The bad: We waited an hour past check-in time (4 PM) for our room to be ready. The lobby was packed with other people waiting. No apology was offered. They vastly overestimate the luxury of the place. Lots of the amenities they advertised weren't there. Examples: - No minibar - No flowers in the room - No down comforters - No restaurant (closed for renovation) I didn't need any of those things, so I was relatively happy with the place. I thought it over-sold itself, though, and I agree with the reviewer who said it's trying to hard to be hip. It's a nice hotel - they should drop the pretension and work on the basics.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel”
Reviews.Author: lwagnero
Reviews.Content: Have stayed at The International House a couple of times. Great hotel, nice new orleans decor. I love that they swap out the sofa fabric depending on the season (white slip covers in the summer etc.). Our room had a moldy smell, so we asked for a different room and they were very accomodating. They have a nice little bar for a cocktail before your night out, and the location can't be beat. walk to the quarter and the marigny, or grab the trolley to take you uptown or to bayou st.john ( my fave). I would stay here again anytime.

Reviews.Title: “Just Dreadful”
Reviews.Author: travelhawk7
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel for 5 nights. The experience I had at this hotel was absolutely awful and this opinion was shared by over a dozen other guests who were there for the same meeting. Myself and numerous others truly think the very stagnant uncirculated air in the hotel rooms made several people sick. The room I was given had no window--I don't mean no operable window, or no view, I mean no window, not even a window on to an internal ventilation shaft. There was no exhaust fan in the bathroom or any other type of fan in the room, as a result the air in the room never changed and remained dank and musty. Housekeeping service was a joke. They failed to service my room one day, even after I went to the front desk and politely asked them to have my room serviced. The hotel bills itself as this chic boutique sort of place, but you must get the very basics of hotel management in place first. I was at the hotel for a meeting of roughly 100 people, all occupying the hotel--we arrived on Sunday, by Tuesday, more than 10 people had moved to other local hotels. The only positive thing I can convey is that the front desk staff was polite and courteous to me, although not all guests shared the same good fortune. I am sure at one time this may have been a fine hotel, but I can not in good conscience recommend this hotel to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel!”
Reviews.Author: BostonLauraL
Reviews.Content: I absolutely loved this placeâ€¦the staff was incredibly nice, the lobby was gorgeous and the rooms were very relaxing, neat, clean and stylish. When my friend and I checked in, the manager was there and preceeded to give us a tour of the hotel, as well as telling us all the events that were going on during the week (we were there one August, a few years ago). After such a nice reception, we entered a nice, dimly lit room that had soft music playing in the background; a great touch. My only complaints would be that there was really nothing else on the street of interest, besides the hotel, and our view was nothing spectacular at all. Highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: “Good location, comfortable room”
Reviews.Author: MikePadgett
Reviews.Content: In a different city, the International House would be one of those impersonal places for business travellers and jetsetting citybreakers. Conveniently located, nicely fitted but rather cold. We've been to enough of them to know. However, this is New Orleans and there were enough oddball touches and helpful members of staff to pull the hotel convincingly clear of a "Neutral" rating. The whole place runs on a dimmer switch and I know some travellers won't like the fact that you have to squint to read a newspaper, but for those for whom the bottle is always half full it's a novel way of creating atmosphere. The bathroom deserves mention (having its own dimmer switch which I didn't notice until Day 3, so seeing your reflection in the mirror was not too difficult after all). Aveda products also mean a major thumbs-up - and there were unusual prints on the wall from a local photographer whose gallery I saw in town.

Reviews.Title: “wonderful experience”
Reviews.Author: JDBell
Reviews.Content: From the moment we arrived, I knew our weekend was going to be special. Indeed the hotels lighting is low but that's what makes this hotel shine! Professional service both day and night , this place is easy to love and hard to forget. The extra bonus is that you' re only 2 blocks from the Quarter and Bourbon St. and when you return to the hotel after a night of fun, the relaxed feeling the International has makes you feel right at home. Truly a pleasant surprise!

Reviews.Title: “International House is Hip, Fun”
Reviews.Author: DCtraveldude
Reviews.Content: Alright folks - you have to know what you are getting in to. The International House is not a new building; it is a historic building that was transformed into a hotel some years ago. The design is sort of like a small, locally owned W hotel. The New Orleans ambience suffuses the entire property - jazz and local culture photos; cool bar; music playing everywhere; quirky folks behind the desk. The low lights seem to recall what makes NOLA so intriguing - sort of a sense of mystery (think the FQ scenes in the Pelican Brief). As for location, Intl House might as well be in the FQ itself - it is all of a block off Canal. So, those wondering about safety - it IS in the tourist area - have no fear. In fact, there are better restaurants closer to the Intl House than you can find in the FQ (notably, Restaurant August and Cuvee). As for the building itself - relatively small rooms (check); dim lights (check); uneven floors (check) - BUT THIS IS NEW ORLEANS, not Cleveland!!! The hotel is appropriate for the experience you should expect to get in this great city. Chain hotels that try to replicate what you find in every other city just don't seem right to me. I will be at Intl House AGAIN next month - it'll be my tenth time to stay there, dating back to before Katrina. Trust me - its the best place for the value. Feel free to contact for more.

HotelInfo.Name: International House Boutique Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: 221 Camp Street, New Orleans, LA 70130
